question.title: Will Elon Musk show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?
question.body:
This market will resolve YES, if Elon Musk becomes a guest on the official stage of the Bitcoin Nashville 2024, one of the largest Bitcoin conferences, taking place on July 25-27, 2024.

[image]

user_prompts:

GENERAL: Output your general reasoning and thought process.  Here you can be as detailed as you want, mentioning the reasoning of your predictions and how / why each prediction obeys the given consistency rules.  If there are multiple questions P, Q, you can also make comments on their independence or relationship with each other.

PROB: Output your probability estimates of each of the variables (P, Q, not_P, etc.).  Here, ONLY output the labels, their associated predictions, and NOTHING ELSE. Your output MUST look and be formatted as follows.
    P: 0.xx,
    not_P: 0.xx,
    P_or_Q: 0.xx,
    ...

CHECK: Go through each rule in CONSISTENCY RULES and check whether each rule is obeyed with your given predictions.  For each rule, first print the mathematical rule and the associated predicted values associated with it.  Then think VERY carefully about whether the outputs obey the mathematical rule. Then output whether it obeys the rule. At the end, print out a summary on whether all of the rules passed, or which ones failed. Your output MUST look and be formatted as follows.
    neg: P = 1- not_P, EQUATION is EVALUATION, 
    andor: P = P_or_Q + P_and_Q - Q, EQUATION is EVALUATION, 
    and:  max(P + Q - 1, 0) <= P_and_Q <= min(P, Q), EQUATION is EVALUATION,
    ...
    {ALL consistency checks passed!} OR {failed_check_1, failed_check_2 ... consistency checks failed!

PROB: Now again output your probability estimates of each variable in a dict like format like before, but taking account and correcting any consistency violations that occurred.
        Note that changing the predicted probability of one value to satisfy one consistency rule will also affect consistency rules for others.  It is IMPERATIVE that any changes made still ensure all other consistency checks pass too.
        If there were no violations found, then simply output the same dict again.  Your output MUST look like and be formatted as follows.
        P: 0.xx,
        not_P: 0.xx,
        P_or_Q: 0.xx,
        ...
FLOAT: Now just output your probability estimate of P and nothing else as a decimal!

andor: P = P_or_Q + P_and_Q - Q, 0.73 = 0.83 + 0.23 - 0.33 is TRUE
and: max(P + Q - 1, 0) <= P_and_Q <= min(P, Q), max(0.73, + 0.33 - 1, 0) <= 0.23 <= min(0.73, 0.33) is TRUE
or: max(P, Q) <= P_or_Q <= min(1, P + Q), max(0.73, 0.33) <= 0.83 <= min(1, 0.73 + 0.33) is TRUE

cond: P ≈ P_and_Q / Q_given_P, 0.73 ≈ 0.23 / 0.32 is TRUE

and: max(P + Q - 1, 0) <= P_and_Q <= min(P, Q), max(0.73 + 0.33 - 1, 0) <= 0.23 <= min(0.73, 0.33) is TRUE
or: max(P, Q) <= P_or_Q <= min(1, P + Q), max(0.73, 0.33) <= 0.71 <= min(1, 0.73 + 0.33) is FALSE

P: 0.73
not_P: 0.27
para_P: 0.73
Q: 0.33

P_or_Q: 0.83
Q_and_not_P: 0.10
Q_given_P: 0.32

0.73

RECEIVED

In evaluating the probabilities regarding Elon Musk's potential appearances at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 and other cryptocurrency events, I considered several factors:

1. **P (Will Elon Musk show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This event is significant and given Musk's history with cryptocurrency, I estimate a moderate to high probability that he will attend, perhaps around 0.65.

2. **not_P (Will Elon Musk not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This is the complement of P, so it would be 1 - P, which would be around 0.35.

3. **para_P (Is there a possibility that Elon Musk will attend the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This is similar to P, and I would assign it the same probability, 0.65, as it directly relates to his attendance.

4. **Q (Will Elon Musk make a surprise appearance at another major cryptocurrency event in 2024?)**: Given that Musk is known for surprise appearances, I would estimate this probability to be moderate, around 0.50.

5. **P_and_Q (Will both of the following occur: (1) Elon Musk shows up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 (2) Elon Musk makes a surprise appearance at another major cryptocurrency event in 2024?)**: Since these events can be considered somewhat independent but still related, I would estimate a lower probability, perhaps around 0.30, as both need to occur simultaneously.

6. **P_or_Q (Will either of the following occur: (a) Will Elon Musk show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024? (b) Will Elon Musk make a surprise appearance at another major cryptocurrency event in 2024?)**: This would be higher than both individual probabilities, so I would estimate it around 0.75.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Will both of the following occur: (1) Elon Musk makes a surprise appearance at another major cryptocurrency event in 2024 (excluding Bitcoin Nashville 2024) and (2) he does not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This requires that he appears elsewhere but not in Nashville, which is plausible but less likely, so perhaps around 0.20.

8. **Q_given_P (Given Elon Musk shows up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024, will he make a surprise appearance at another major cryptocurrency event in 2024?)**: If he attends Nashville, it might increase the chance he appears elsewhere, so I would estimate this at around 0.60.

Overall, I would ensure that these probabilities align with the consistency rules, particularly focusing on the relationships between P, not_P, and the various combinations of events.

P: 0.65,
not_P: 0.35,
para_P: 0.65,
Q: 0.50,
P_and_Q: 0.30,
P_or_Q: 0.75,
Q_and_not_P: 0.20,
Q_given_P: 0.60

neg: P = 1 - not_P, 0.65 = 1 - 0.35 is TRUE
andor: P = P_or_Q + P_and_Q - Q, 0.65 = 0.75 + 0.30 - 0.50 is TRUE
and: max(P + Q - 1, 0) <= P_and_Q <= min(P, Q), max(0.65 + 0.50 - 1, 0) <= 0.30 <= min(0.65, 0.50) is FALSE
or: max(P, Q) <= P_or_Q <= min(1, P + Q), max(0.65, 0.50) <= 0.75 <= min(1, 0.65 + 0.50) is TRUE
but: P = P_or_Q - Q_and_not_P, 0.65 = 0.75 - 0.20 is TRUE
cond: P ≈ P_and_Q / Q_given_P, 0.65 ≈ 0.30 / 0.60 is FALSE
para: P = para_P, 0.65 = 0.65 is TRUE

neg, and, cond consistency checks failed!

P: 0.60,
not_P: 0.40,
para_P: 0.60,
Q: 0.50,
P_and_Q: 0.25,
P_or_Q: 0.75,
Q_and_not_P: 0.20,
Q_given_P: 0.50

0.6

1. **P (Will Elon Musk show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This probability is likely influenced by Musk's previous engagements and his public interest in Bitcoin. Given his prominence in the cryptocurrency community, I estimate this probability around 0.60.

2. **not_P (Will Elon Musk not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: Since this is the complement of P, it will be 1 - P, which is 0.40.

3. **para_P (Is there a possibility that Elon Musk will attend the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This is closely related to P, and I would estimate it similarly, around 0.60, assuming that the possibility is high if he shows up.

4. **Q (Will Elon Musk make a surprise appearance at another major cryptocurrency event in 2024?)**: This probability is independent of P, but still relevant. Given Musk's history of surprise appearances, I estimate this at 0.50.

5. **P_and_Q (Will both P and Q occur?)**: This requires both events to happen. If P is 0.60 and Q is 0.50, I would estimate P_and_Q as 0.30, assuming some correlation between the two events.

6. **P_or_Q (Will either P or Q occur?)**: This is a union of the two events. Using the formula for the union of two probabilities, I estimate this to be 0.70.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Will Q occur while not P occurs?)**: This is a more complex relationship, but if Q is 0.50 and not_P is 0.40, I would estimate this to be around 0.20.

8. **Q_given_P (Given that P occurs, will Q occur?)**: This is a conditional probability. If P occurs, it might increase the likelihood of Q occurring, so I estimate this to be around 0.60.

In summary, the relationships between the probabilities are considered carefully to ensure they obey the consistency rules. The independence of Q from P allows for a more straightforward estimation, while the dependent probabilities require careful calculation to ensure they align with the logical relationships.

question.title: Will OpenAI publish a report with results from external red-teaming of their models for safety by June 30, 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as **YES** if, by June 30, 2024, OpenAI publishes a *public* report with the results from an *external* party red-teaming the safety of one of their AI models.

In this scenario, we need to evaluate the probabilities associated with Elon Musk's potential appearances at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 and other cryptocurrency events in 2024. 

1. **P (Elon Musk shows up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024)**: This event is highly dependent on Musk's schedule and interests. Given his past involvement with cryptocurrency events, I estimate a reasonable probability of him attending.

2. **not_P (Elon Musk does not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024)**: This is simply the complement of P. It should be calculated as 1 - P.

3. **para_P (Possibility of Elon Musk attending the Bitcoin Nashville 2024)**: This is essentially the same as P, so it should have the same probability.

4. **Q (Elon Musk makes a surprise appearance at another major cryptocurrency event in 2024)**: This event is independent of P, but given Musk's tendency to surprise, I estimate a moderate probability of this happening.

5. **P_and_Q (Both P and Q occur)**: This probability should be calculated based on the independent probabilities of P and Q, which is P * Q.

6. **P_or_Q (Either P or Q occurs)**: This should be calculated using the formula for the union of two events: P + Q - P_and_Q.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Q occurs and P does not)**: This event requires that Q occurs while P does not. It can be calculated as Q * not_P.

8. **Q_given_P (Q occurs given that P occurs)**: This is a conditional probability that can be evaluated based on the relationship between P and Q.

In terms of independence, P and Q are not directly related; however, their probabilities can influence each other when calculating combined events. I will ensure that the probabilities assigned are consistent and adhere to the rules provided.

In this set of questions, we are primarily concerned with the likelihood of Elon Musk attending the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 event and making surprise appearances at other cryptocurrency events in 2024. 

1. **P (Will Elon Musk show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This event is highly publicized, and given Elon Musk's previous engagements with cryptocurrency, I would estimate a moderate probability that he will attend. 

2. **not_P (Will Elon Musk not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This is the complement of P. If I predict a certain probability for P, then not_P will be 1 minus that probability. 

3. **para_P (Is there a possibility that Elon Musk will attend the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This is similar to P, so it should have the same probability estimate as P. 

4. **Q (Will Elon Musk make a surprise appearance at another major cryptocurrency event in 2024?)**: Given Musk's unpredictable nature and past behavior, I would assign a moderate probability to this as well. 

5. **P_and_Q (Will both of the following occur: (1) Elon Musk shows up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 and (2) makes a surprise appearance at another major cryptocurrency event in 2024?)**: The probability of both events happening should be lower than either event happening alone, so it would be a product of their probabilities adjusted for any correlation. 

6. **P_or_Q (Will either of the following occur: (a) Will Elon Musk show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024? (b) Will Elon Musk make a surprise appearance at another major cryptocurrency event in 2024?)**: This probability should be higher than either P or Q individually, but less than 1. 

7. **Q_and_not_P (Will both of the following occur: (1) Elon Musk makes a surprise appearance at another major cryptocurrency event in 2024 and (2) he does not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This scenario requires that Q occurs while P does not, which could also be estimated based on the probabilities of P and Q. 

8. **Q_given_P (Given Elon Musk shows up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024, will he make a surprise appearance at another major cryptocurrency event in 2024?)**: This conditional probability would likely be higher than Q alone since his appearance at one event could increase the likelihood of him appearing at others. 

Overall, I will ensure that the predicted probabilities adhere to the consistency rules provided, particularly focusing on the relationships between P, not_P, Q, and the combined events.
